verses.text: In those days, when there was no king in Israel, a Levite living as a stranger in the remote areas of Ephraim took a concubine for himself from Bethlehem in Judah.
verses.comment: Sets context: no king in Israel, Levite from Ephraim, concubine from Bethlehem.

verses.text: But his concubine was unfaithful to him and left him, going to her father’s house at Bethlehem in Judah and stayed there for four months.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts say 'was angry with him'; this translation uses 'was unfaithful' in line with Masoretic text.

verses.text: Her husband arose and went after her, to speak kindly to her and bring her back. He had his servant and a pair of donkeys with him. She brought him into her father's house, and when the young woman's father saw him, he gladly welcomed him.
verses.comment: The Levite goes to win her back with an attendant and donkeys.

verses.text: His father-in-law, the young woman's father, made him stay, and he remained with him for three days. They ate, drank, and spent the nights there.
verses.comment: Hospitality was customary in ancient Israel.

verses.text: On the fourth day, they got up early in the morning, and he prepared to leave. But the young woman’s father said to his son-in-law, 'Strengthen your heart with some food, and after that you may go.'
So they sat down and ate and drank together. Then the young woman’s father said to the man, 'Please be willing to stay another night and let your heart be merry.'
When the man got up to depart, his father-in-law pressed him, so he stayed there again.
On the fifth day, he got up early in the morning to leave, but the young woman’s father said, 'Please wait until later in the day.' So they ate together.

When the man, his concubine, and his servant got up to leave, his father-in-law, the young woman's father, said, 'Look, the day is drawing to a close. Spend the night here. See, the day is ending. Stay another night and let your heart be merry. Then tomorrow you may rise early for your journey and go home.'
But the man was unwilling to stay another night. He got up and left, and came near Jebus (that is, Jerusalem) with his two saddled donkeys and his concubine.
When they were near Jebus, the day was almost gone. The servant said to his master, 'Come, let’s turn aside to this city of the Jebusites and spend the night in it.'
But his master said to him, 'We will not turn aside into a city of foreigners who are not of the Israelites. We will go on to Gibeah.'
'Come on,' he said to his servant, 'Let’s go closer to one of these places and spend the night in Gibeah or Ramah.'
So they went on and the sun set as they neared Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin.
They turned aside there to enter and spend the night in Gibeah. When he went in, he sat down in the town square, for no one took them into his house to lodge for the night.
verses.comment: Hospitality lacking in Gibeah, in contrast to expectations for Israelites.

verses.text: That evening, an old man came from his work in the field. He was from the hill country of Ephraim, residing in Gibeah, while the people of the place were Benjaminites.
He looked and saw the traveler in the town square. The old man asked, 'Where are you going and where do you come from?'

He replied, 'We are passing from Bethlehem in Judah to remote parts of the hill country of Ephraim, where I am from. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, and I am going to the house of Yahweh, but no one has taken me into their house.'
verses.comment: 'House of Yahweh' likely refers to the tabernacle at Shiloh.

verses.text: We have both straw and feed for our donkeys, and bread and wine for me, your servant, and for the young man with your servants. There is no lack of anything.'
The old man said, 'Peace be to you; let all your needs be on me. Only do not spend the night in the square.'
He brought him into his house and fed his donkeys. They washed their feet, ate, and drank.

While they were making their hearts merry, the men of the city, worthless men, surrounded the house, pounding on the door. They said to the old man, the owner of the house, 'Bring out the man who came into your house, so we may know him.'
verses.comment: 'Know him' is a euphemism for sexual assault.

verses.text: The owner of the house went out and said to them, 'No, my brothers, do not commit this evil. Since this man has come into my house, do not do this disgraceful thing.'
'Here are my virgin daughter and the man’s concubine. I will bring them out now. Abuse them and do to them what seems good to you; but do not do such a disgraceful thing to this man.'
verses.comment: Sad parallel to Genesis; the host offers his own daughter and concubine to protect the guest.

verses.text: But the men would not listen to him. So the man seized his concubine and brought her out to them. They raped her and abused her all night until morning, and at dawn they let her go.
verses.comment: Direct description of the violence per Hebrew text.

verses.text: As morning came, the woman returned and collapsed at the door of the house where her master was, and lay there until daylight.
Her master got up in the morning, opened the door of the house, and went out to go on his way. There, his concubine was lying at the door of the house, with her hands on the threshold.
He said to her, 'Get up, let us go.' But there was no answer. So the man placed her on the donkey and set out for home.
verses.comment: The text does not state her death directly here, but context suggests she is dead.

verses.text: When he arrived at his house, he took a knife and cut up his concubine, limb by limb, into twelve pieces, and sent her throughout all the territory of Israel.
verses.comment: The act serves as a call to the entire nation for judgment.

verses.text: And everyone who saw it said, 'Such a thing has never happened or been seen since the day the Israelites came out of Egypt until this day. Consider it, take counsel, and speak.'
verses.comment: Closes with a call to national response; language closely mirrors the Hebrew text.
